lessons.title: Capital Gains Tax on Investments
lessons.videoTopic: LTCG, STCG, and Tax Rates Explained

content.original: Capital gains = Profit from selling capital assets. STCG (Short-Term Capital Gains) = Holding period <12 months (equity), <36 months (debt). LTCG (Long-Term Capital Gains) = Beyond these periods. Equity STCG: 20% tax. Equity LTCG: 12.5% tax on gains above ‚Çπ1.25 lakh/year. Debt STCG: Added to income, taxed at slab rate. Debt LTCG: 12.5% without indexation. Listed bonds/debentures now treated like debt funds. Cost of acquisition, brokerage, STT included in cost base. Advance tax applicable if tax liability >‚Çπ10,000. Maintain records of all transactions for ITR filing.
content.simplified: When you sell investments and make profit, you pay tax. Two types: Short-term (held <1 year for stocks) = 20% tax. Long-term (held >1 year for stocks) = 12.5% tax, but first ‚Çπ1.25 lakh profit every year is tax-free. Example: You invest ‚Çπ1L in stock, sell after 2 years for ‚Çπ3L. Profit = ‚Çπ2L. First ‚Çπ1.25L tax-free, remaining ‚Çπ0.75L taxed at 12.5% = ‚Çπ9,375 tax. If you sold in 10 months (short-term), entire ‚Çπ2L taxed at 20% = ‚Çπ40,000 tax. Big difference! Lesson: Hold >1 year when possible. For debt mutual funds, different rules apply - usually added to your income.

lessons.aiSummary: Capital gains tax: Equity STCG (<1yr) = 20%, LTCG (>1yr) = 12.5% above ‚Çπ1.25L exemption. Debt STCG = Slab rate, LTCG = 12.5% without indexation. Holding period crucial for tax efficiency.
keyTakeaways: ‚Çπ1.25 lakh equity LTCG exemption per year (use strategically)
Holding >1 year reduces tax from 20% to 12.5% (equity)
STT (Securities Transaction Tax) paid automatically during trades
Keep transaction statements for ITR filing proof
commonMistakes: Selling winners before 1 year (unnecessary high tax)
Not utilizing ‚Çπ1.25L exemption annually (sell some holdings strategically)
Not maintaining purchase records (can't prove cost basis)
Forgetting to include dividend income in ITR (taxable at slab rate)

lessons.title: Tax-Saving Investment Options

content.original: Section 80C: ‚Çπ1.5 lakh deduction. Options: PPF (7.1%, 15yr lock-in, tax-free returns), ELSS mutual funds (equity exposure, 3yr lock-in, market-linked), EPF (employer contribution), NSC, Tax-saver FD, Life insurance premium, Home loan principal, Sukanya Samriddhi (for girl child). Section 80D: ‚Çπ25,000 for health insurance (‚Çπ50,000 if senior citizen), additional ‚Çπ25,000 for parents. NPS (National Pension System): Additional ‚Çπ50,000 deduction under 80CCD(1B). New tax regime: No deductions available, lower rates. Choose regime based on deductions available. Old regime beneficial if deductions >‚Çπ2.5L.
content.simplified: Government gives tax benefits for certain investments: Section 80C (‚Çπ1.5L limit): Best options - (1) ELSS funds: 3-year lock-in, equity returns, better than FD. (2) PPF: Safe, 7% return, 15-year lock-in, completely tax-free. (3) EPF: Auto-deducted from salary. Section 80D: Health insurance premium - save ‚Çπ25,000 for yourself, ‚Çπ25,000 for parents. Tax saved = ‚Çπ15,000-20,000 depending on slab. NPS: Extra ‚Çπ50,000 deduction (above 80C limit). Important: New tax regime gives NO deductions but lower rates. Calculate which regime better for you. If you have home loan, medical insurance, investments - old regime usually better.

lessons.aiSummary: Tax-saving: Section 80C (‚Çπ1.5L - PPF, ELSS, EPF, insurance), 80D (‚Çπ25K health insurance, ‚Çπ50K if senior), 80CCD(1B) (‚Çπ50K NPS). Old regime = deductions, New regime = lower rates, no deductions. Choose wisely.
keyTakeaways: ELSS has shortest lock-in (3yr) among 80C options, equity exposure
PPF is safest 80C option, completely tax-free (EEE status)
Health insurance deduction separate from 80C (stack benefits)
NPS gives additional ‚Çπ50K deduction beyond 80C limit
commonMistakes: Buying insurance just for tax saving (insurance need and tax separate)
Choosing tax-saver FD over ELSS (lower returns, same lock-in)
Not opting for new regime when beneficial (no deductions available)
Last-minute 80C investment in March (poor planning)

lessons.title: Tax-Loss Harvesting & Optimization

content.original: Tax-loss harvesting = Selling losing positions to offset gains and reduce tax liability. LTCG losses can offset LTCG gains, STCG losses offset both LTCG and STCG. Strategy: Sell losers in year with big gains to neutralize tax. Can buyback same stock immediately (no wash-sale rule in India). Use ‚Çπ1.25L LTCG exemption optimally - book gains annually to use exemption. Dividend income taxable at slab rate - consider growth option over dividend option in MFs. Gift to spouse/children to utilize their lower tax bracket (clubbing provisions apply for minors). Offset gains across asset classes strategically. Maintain detailed records. Tax filing by 31st July mandatory for capital gains.
content.simplified: Tax-loss harvesting = Smart way to reduce tax. Example: You made ‚Çπ3L profit on Stock A (will pay tax). Stock B is showing ‚Çπ1L loss (on paper). Sell Stock B before March 31 - your taxable profit becomes ‚Çπ2L instead of ‚Çπ3L. You can buyback Stock B immediately next day if you still like it (allowed in India). Another trick: Every year, book some profits to use ‚Çπ1.25L tax-free limit. If you don't sell anything, you waste this exemption. Example: Stocks worth ‚Çπ10L grown to ‚Çπ12L. Sell ‚Çπ1.25L profit worth stocks before March, buy back immediately. Now your cost base increased (saves future tax). Smart investors do this annually. Also: Mutual funds - choose Growth option, not Dividend (dividends taxed every year, growth taxed only when you sell).

lessons.aiSummary: Tax-loss harvesting = Offset gains with losses to reduce tax. STCG losses offset both types, LTCG losses offset LTCG only. Use ‚Çπ1.25L exemption annually. No wash-sale rule (can buyback immediately). Growth > Dividend option in MFs. File ITR by July 31.
keyTakeaways: Harvest losses before March 31 to offset gains in same financial year
Can repurchase sold stocks immediately (no waiting period)
Book ‚Çπ1.25L LTCG annually to avoid wasting exemption
Growth option in MFs more tax-efficient than dividend option
commonMistakes: Not harvesting losses (paying unnecessary tax)
Wasting ‚Çπ1.25L annual exemption by not booking any gains
Choosing dividend option (unnecessary tax every year)
Not planning tax moves before financial year end (March 31)

lessons.title: SEBI Regulations & Investor Protection

content.original: SEBI (Securities and Exchange Board of India) = Market regulator. Functions: (1) Protect investor interests, (2) Regulate intermediaries (brokers, advisors), (3) Prevent market manipulation and insider trading. Key regulations: Broker must be SEBI-registered. Investment advisors need RIA (Registered Investment Advisor) license. SEBI SCORES platform for investor complaints. Insider trading = Trading on unpublished price-sensitive information (criminal offense, ‚Çπ25Cr fine + jail). Front-running illegal. Pump-and-dump schemes prohibited. Circuit breakers halt trading during extreme volatility. Investor Grievance Redressal: SCORES ‚Üí Exchange ‚Üí Ombudsman ‚Üí SAT (Securities Appellate Tribunal). Check SEBI registration before trusting anyone.
content.simplified: SEBI = Stock market police. Protects you from frauds and ensures fair trading. Key points: (1) Only use SEBI-registered brokers (Zerodha, Groww, etc. are registered). Check on SEBI website before opening account. (2) If someone gives paid investment advice, they MUST have RIA license. Many telegram/YouTube channels illegal. (3) Got cheated? File complaint on SEBI SCORES website (sebi.gov.in/scores). SEBI will investigate and help recover money. (4) Insider trading = Buying stocks because you know company news before public (like CEO buying before good results announcement). This is crime - 10 year jail possible. (5) If someone promises guaranteed returns or asks you to invest in 'sure-shot' tips - report to SEBI. Remember: If it sounds too good to be true, it is.

keyTakeaways: Always verify SEBI registration of broker/advisor before trusting
SCORES platform is free and effective for investor complaints
Insider trading carries severe penalties (‚Çπ25Cr + jail)
Circuit breakers protect market during extreme movements
commonMistakes: Using unregistered brokers (money safety risk)
Following unlicensed advisors on social media
Not filing complaints when cheated (letting fraudsters continue)
Sharing trading tips based on company insider knowledge (crime)

lessons.title: KYC, PAN, and Compliance Essentials

content.original: KYC (Know Your Customer) = Mandatory for all financial transactions. Types: (1) Aadhaar-based e-KYC (instant, paperless), (2) In-person verification (IPV). Documents needed: PAN card (mandatory for investments), Aadhaar, Address proof, Bank details, Photo. PAN mandatory for: Stock trading, MF investments above ‚Çπ50,000, opening demat account. Linking Aadhaar with PAN mandatory (penalty if not done). One KYC valid across all segments (mutual funds, stocks, insurance). FATCA declaration for foreign tax residency. Nominee addition important for succession. Annual ITR filing mandatory if: Total income >‚Çπ2.5L, Capital gains from investments, Foreign assets. Advance tax payment required if tax liability >‚Çπ10,000. TDS on interest, dividends auto-deducted. Form 26AS shows all tax deductions - verify before filing ITR.
content.simplified: Documents and rules you must know: (1) PAN card: Must have for investing. Links all your investments. Without PAN, can't buy stocks or mutual funds. (2) Aadhaar: Link with PAN (deadline extended multiple times but do it now). (3) KYC: One-time process using PAN + Aadhaar. Do e-KYC online in 10 minutes. Once done, valid everywhere (Zerodha, Groww, all MF companies). (4) Must file Income Tax Return (ITR) if: Your income >‚Çπ2.5L/year OR you sold any investment and made profit (even ‚Çπ1). Don't skip - penalty ‚Çπ5,000. (5) Add nominee: If something happens to you, nominee gets your investments. Without nominee, family faces problems. (6) Form 26AS: Shows all taxes deducted from your salary, interest, dividends. Download from IT portal before filing ITR (ensures you get credit for all TDS).

lessons.aiSummary: Compliance essentials: KYC mandatory (PAN + Aadhaar + address), Link Aadhaar-PAN (penalty if not), One KYC for all segments, Nominee addition important, ITR filing mandatory if income >‚Çπ2.5L or capital gains, Form 26AS verification before filing.
keyTakeaways: PAN is foundation - needed for all investments
Aadhaar-PAN linking mandatory (hefty penalty for non-compliance)
e-KYC takes 10 minutes, valid for all financial products
Adding nominee prevents legal hassles for family
commonMistakes: Not linking Aadhaar with PAN (PAN becomes inoperative)
Not adding nominee in demat/MF accounts
Not filing ITR despite capital gains (notices and penalties)
Not verifying Form 26AS before ITR (miss TDS credit)
